conclusion: Understanding the relationship between volume V, temperature T, and pressure p of an ideal gas using the ideal gas law.
The ideal gas law is given by pV = nRT, where n is the number of moles of gas, R is the gas constant, and T is the temperature in Kelvin.
Given conditions: pA = p0, TA = T0, AB is parallel to the V axis, BC is over the origin, work done by the gas from state A to state B is 10 J.
Finding the volume V at state A using the formula V_A = nRT_A/p0.
Finding the volume V at state B using the formula V_B = nRT_B/2p0.
Since AB is parallel to the V axis, setting V_A = V_B.
Finding the temperature T_B at state B as T_B = 2T_A.
The work done by the gas on the outside world is equal to the change in internal energy of the gas, W = ΔU.
The change in internal energy ΔU is equal to the heat absorbed by the gas, ΔU = Q.
The heat absorbed by the gas is equal to the work done by the gas on the outside world, Q = W.
Substituting the work done by the gas gives Q = 10 J.
